traits.smithy.api#documentation: Adds device(s) to your account (i.e., claim one or more devices) if and only if you received a claim code with the device(s).
The claim code, starting with "C-", as provided by the device manufacturer.
The claim code provided by the device manufacturer.
The total number of devices associated with the claim code that has been processed in the claim request.
Given a device ID, returns a DescribeDeviceResponse object describing the details of the device.
The unique identifier of the device.
Device details.
The user specified attributes associated with the device for an event.
The unique identifier of the device.
The device type, such as "button".
DeviceAttributes is a string-to-string map specified by the user.
The ARN of the device.
An array of zero or more elements of DeviceAttribute objects providing user specified device attributes.
The unique identifier of the device.
A Boolean value indicating whether or not the device is enabled.
A value between 0 and 1 inclusive, representing the fraction of life remaining for the device.
The type of the device, such as "button".
The tags currently associated with the AWS IoT 1-Click device.
An object representing the device associated with the event.
A serialized JSON object representing the device-type specific event.
The type of the device, such as "button".
The name of the method applicable to the deviceType.

Given a device ID, finalizes the claim request for the associated device.

Claiming a device consists of initiating a claim, then publishing a device event, and finalizing the claim. For a device of type button, a device event can be published by simply clicking the device.
The unique identifier of the device.
A collection of key/value pairs defining the resource tags. For example, { "tags": {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2"} }. For more information, see AWS Tagging Strategies.
The device's final claim state.
The 403 error message returned by the web server.
Given a device ID, returns the invokable methods associated with the device.
The unique identifier of the device.
List of available device APIs.

Given a device ID, initiates a claim request for the associated device.

Claiming a device consists of initiating a claim, then publishing a device event, and finalizing the claim. For a device of type button, a device event can be published by simply clicking the device.
The unique identifier of the device.
The device's final claim state.
The 500 error message returned by the web server.
The 400 error message returned by the web server.
Given a device ID, issues a request to invoke a named device method (with possible parameters). See the "Example POST" code snippet below.
The unique identifier of the device.
The device method to invoke.
A JSON encoded string containing the device method request parameters.
A JSON encoded string containing the device method response.
Describes all of the AWS IoT 1-Click device-related API operations for the service. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

Region.documentation: The AWS region used to dispatch the request.

UseDualStack.documentation: When true, use the dual-stack endpoint. If the configured endpoint does not support dual-stack, dispatching the request MAY return an error.

UseFIPS.documentation: When true, send this request to the FIPS-compliant regional endpoint. If the configured endpoint does not have a FIPS compliant endpoint, dispatching the request will return an error.

Endpoint.documentation: Override the endpoint used to send this request

rules.error: Invalid Configuration: FIPS and custom endpoint are not supported
Invalid Configuration: Dualstack and custom endpoint are not supported
FIPS and DualStack are enabled, but this partition does not support one or both
FIPS is enabled but this partition does not support FIPS
DualStack is enabled but this partition does not support DualStack

testCases.documentation: For region us-west-2 with FIPS enabled and DualStack enabled
For region us-west-2 with FIPS enabled and DualStack disabled
For region us-west-2 with FIPS disabled and DualStack enabled
For region us-west-2 with FIPS disabled and DualStack disabled
For custom endpoint with fips disabled and dualstack disabled
For custom endpoint with fips enabled and dualstack disabled

expect.error: Invalid Configuration: FIPS and custom endpoint are not supported

testCases.documentation: For custom endpoint with fips disabled and dualstack enabled

expect.error: Invalid Configuration: Dualstack and custom endpoint are not supported

traits.smithy.api#documentation: Using a device ID, returns a DeviceEventsResponse object containing an array of events for the device.
The unique identifier of the device.
The start date for the device event query, in ISO8061 format. For example, 2018-03-28T15:45:12.880Z
The maximum number of results to return per request. If not set, a default value of 100 is used.
The token to retrieve the next set of results.
The end date for the device event query, in ISO8061 format. For example, 2018-03-28T15:45:12.880Z
An array of zero or more elements describing the event(s) associated with the device.
The token to retrieve the next set of results.
Lists the 1-Click compatible devices associated with your AWS account.
The type of the device, such as "button".
The maximum number of results to return per request. If not set, a default value of 100 is used.
The token to retrieve the next set of results.
A list of devices.
The token to retrieve the next set of results.
Lists the tags associated with the specified resource ARN.
The ARN of the resource.
A collection of key/value pairs defining the resource tags. For example, { "tags": {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2"} }. For more information, see AWS Tagging Strategies.
An error message explaining the error or its remedy.
The requested number of results specified by nextToken cannot be satisfied.
An error message explaining the error or its remedy.
The requested device could not be found.
Adds or updates the tags associated with the resource ARN. See AWS IoT 1-Click Service Limits for the maximum number of tags allowed per resource.
The ARN of the resource.
A collection of key/value pairs defining the resource tags. For example, { "tags": {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2"} }. For more information, see AWS Tagging Strategies.
Disassociates a device from your AWS account using its device ID.
The unique identifier of the device.
The device's final claim state.
Using tag keys, deletes the tags (key/value pairs) associated with the specified resource ARN.
The ARN of the resource.
A collections of tag keys. For example, {"key1","key2"}
Using a Boolean value (true or false), this operation enables or disables the device given a device ID.
The unique identifier of the device.
If true, the device is enabled. If false, the device is disabled.
